author: sky.cactus
content: What do you think we should do when people do spam the repository to get a desirable number?  What do you think we should do when people engage in not-quite-spam tactics to get a desirable number (like submitting unrelated but not entirely spam PRs to drive the number up)?

author: gcolvin
content: Use policy (and a bot?) to prevent the problem happening in the future and move on.  We Editors have survived far more consequential battles.  Thus the bot in the first place.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we automate the checks, people will just figure out ways to game them.  For example, if you disallow PRs within `n` minutes of a previous PR/issue, then people will just set their spam bots to wait `n` minutes.  If you disallow people from submitting multiple PRs in a row, they will just use multiple accounts.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think there is any specific policy we could come up with that cannot be gamed, which is why I favor the vague policy of "editors pick the numbers, not the authors" and then we trust editors to block any *perceived* attempts at sniping/spamming/gaming (it doesn't really matter if they are actual attempts, since false positives are not a problem as it just means someone gets a number other than the PR).

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, that suffers its own problems as editors can choose when to enforce the policy and when not to, which is the failure that occurred here.  The standing policy of not allowing sniping/gaming was overridden by an editor because of what appears to be favoritism for the authors.

author: sky.cactus
content: So either we create a strict policy that prevents editors from playing favorites but enables authors to game the system, or we create a loose policy that allows editors to play favorites but prevents authors from gaming the system.

author: sky.cactus
content: Up until this incident, we had been going with the latter and it was working well (though we did miss some).  This incident created uncertainty that we can trust editors not play favorites, which complicates matters greatly because if we can't trust the editors to not play favorites then I feel like we have bigger problems.

author: hrkrshnn
content:
This seems to be going in circles around three things: allegation of spam, number sniping and credible neutrality. Do you really think the EIP process is *credibly* neutral in the first place? The reviews are not even double-blind.

If you look at the issue 5222 in particular, the authors were accused of number squatting and had their EIP renumbered, despite no indication of the authors performing this. It's only after our protest that this decision was overturned. They seem to be two students and a professor trio, bullied by editors with arbitrary allegations. They were first time contributors and likely new to the space itself. 

To an outsider, all these sound deeply problematic. With calls for firing two other editors, bullying new contributors, renumbering / deleting EIPs, number policing, calling for a coup, and auctioning off numbers for profit.

author: sky.cactus
content:
I have several problems with that strategy:
A. We had a policy (editor assigns the number, which Sam did) but it was ignored.  Creating a new policy doesn't stop editors from ignoring the policy again in the future.
B. If every time someone games the system we allow them to get away with it and then develop new rules going forward, we just incentivize people to game the system and we spend all of our time playing cat & mouse with them.  It would be much simpler to just not allow people to game the system in the first place (which is what our policy did previously by saying editors assign EIP numbers).
C. Ignoring the underlying ethos disagreement still leaves us in a situation where some editors think it is acceptable to treat friends/well known authors differently from unknown authors and this is very likely to cause tension again in the future.
